Graphical abstract Highlights ► Two novel biomimetic catalysts immobilized on clay minerals were synthesized. ► Enhanced reaction rate of the catechol oxidation. ► Immobilized heterogeneous catalysts were more efficient than the free homogeneous catalyst. ► Effective heterogeneous catalysis for at least two sequential reaction cycles. ► Catechol oxidation depended on the amount of immobilized catalyst. Two novel heterogeneous biomimetic catalysts were synthesized by immobilizing a meso-tetra(2,6-dichloro-3-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrinate of manganese (III) chloride on both kaolinite and montmorillonite clay minerals, previously functionalized with a molecular spacer whose terminal nitrogen atom coordinates the metal in the porphyrin ring. The clay functionalization by a 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl-triethoxysilane spacer was proved by X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, DRIFT-IR, 13C- and 29Si-CPMAS-NMR spectroscopies, and the percent of manganese–porphyrin immobilized by the spacer coordination calculated by spectrophotometry. The activity of the novel catalysts was evaluated in the oxidative coupling reaction of catechol, a humic phenol, using H2O2 as oxygen donor. The rate of catechol oxidation catalyzed by both heterogeneous catalysts was about four times as fast as that catalyzed by the free manganese–porphyrin, and depended on the amount of catalyst immobilized on clay minerals. Moreover, the activity of the heterogeneous catalysts remained effective for at least two sequential reaction cycles, although at a decreasing rate. We showed that the immobilization of a biomimetic catalyst on clay minerals increased the catalytic efficiency and allowed the catalyst recycling and reuse for additional reactions. Metal–porphyrins immobilized on clay minerals through a flexible spacer may act as environment-friendly heterogeneous catalysts to control phenolic molecules in environmental humus. Abbreviations Mn(TDCPPS)Cl meso-tetra(2,6-dichloro-3-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrinate of manganese(III) chloride K kaolinite M montmorillonite Imi-APTS 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl-triethoxysilane Keywords Oxidation Biomimetic catalysis Heterogeneous catalysts Humic phenols Phenolic pollutants NMR 1 Introduction In recent years, the interest in using metal–porphyrins as biomimetic catalysts has been progressively growing [1]. Special attention has been focused on the ability of metal–porphyrins to act as model of cytochrome P450 monooxygenases in catalyzing several oxidation reactions of organic and inorganic compounds, under mild conditions [1,2], including the hydroxylation of alkanes [3,4] and epoxidation of alkenes [5,6]. Due to instability of natural metal–porphyrins under oxidizing conditions and poor water solubility [7], attention has been devoted in developing synthetic metal–porphyrins to be more resistant to degradative oxidation and active in aqueous media. These properties have been usually achieved by adding electron-withdrawing groups (such as sulphonatophenyl groups) in the meso positions of metal–porphyrins [8]. Furthermore, sterically and/or electronically protected polychlorinated or polyfluorinated porphyrins were synthesized to increase their stability [7,9,10]. Although efficient homogeneous catalytic systems based on metal–porphyrins have been developed [7,11,12], it has been found that, when metal–porphyrins are free in solution, side reactions, such as self-destruction or formation of μ–oxo porphyrin dimers, limit considerably their catalytic activity [13]. Moreover, their multiple use in solution is not economically viable due to difficulty in catalyst separation, recovery and recycling. To overcome the described limitations of homogeneous catalysis, immobilization of metal–porphyrins on adequate supports has been attempted by different mechanisms: adsorption [9,13–15], ion exchange [16], or covalent bond formation [17,18]. The supported catalysts have both operational and economic advantages, since they allow easy separation of products from the catalyst and catalyst reuse for further reactions. Several materials have been employed to support metal–porphyrins to synthesize heterogeneous catalysts: organic synthetic polymers such as polystyrene [19], biopolymers or inorganic matrices such as silica [17,20], porous vycor glass [15], and zeolites [14]. Metal–porphyrins are reported to be immobilized on montmorillonites by simple adsorption [9,21] or in the interlayer surfaces of kaolinites through their grafting by ethanolamine [22]. However, to our knowledge, there are no earlier attempts to immobilize a metal–porphyrin on a clay mineral functionalized with a molecular spacer, whose terminal is a Lewis acid to coordinate the catalyst metal center, and long enough to minimize unspecific support/porphyrin interactions. A heterogeneous catalyst, such as a metal–porphyrin immobilized on a spacer-functionalized clay mineral, may efficiently enhance the oxidative coupling of phenols and phenol-containing humic molecules in aqueous media. The mechanism of action of metal–porphyrins is induced by an oxygen donor that produces high-valent metal-oxo species which, in turn, oxidize phenolic moieties [23]. Unstable free radicals are formed and then stabilized by mutual couplings, thus resulting into polyphenols consisting of covalently linked phenylene and oxyphenylene units [24,25]. Oxidative coupling of reactive phenols either alone or in humic superstructures were conducted by homogeneous biomimetic catalysis to form new intermolecular covalent bonds among phenolic molecules [26–30]. Biomimetic catalysts such as iron– and manganese–porphyrins were shown to successfully catalyze oxidative coupling reactions of monomeric natural phenols such as catechol, caffeic and p-coumaric acid [26–28], as well as dissolved phenol-containing humic matter under a chemical oxidant [29] or under photo-oxidation [30]. Water-soluble iron–porphyrin was also employed to catalyzed the photopolymerization of humic molecules in situ in soil, with the aim to enhance the microbial stability of soil humus and, thus, reduce its mineralization and consequent CO2 emission [31]. Moreover, an oxidative co-polymerization between phenolic components of humic matter and phenolic pollutants catalyzed by biomimetic porphyrins was found useful to remove polyhalogenated phenols and their analogs from aqueous media [32]. However, no investigation has been reported up to now on the oxidative coupling among humic phenolic precursors under the catalysis of metal–porphyrins immobilized on solid eco-friendly supports such as clay minerals. The aim of this work was, therefore, to immobilize a meso-tetra(2,6-dichloro-3-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrinate of manganese(III) chloride [Mn(TDCPPS)Cl] on both kaolinite and montmorillonite clay minerals, following their functionalization with a molecular spacer to allow a coordinative interaction with Mn. The efficiency of the catalysis induced by the immobilized Mn-porphyrin and the H2O2 oxidant, was studied by following the disappearance of catechol, a phenolic constituent of environmental humus, and comparing the catalytic rate with that obtained by homogeneous catalysis. 2 Experimental All solvents and reagents were of Reagent Grade (Sigma–Aldrich), and used without further purification. The procedure for the synthesis of water-soluble Mn(TDCPPS)Cl, has been described elsewhere [29]. The clay minerals used in this work were a kaolinite (K) from Washington County, Georgia, USA, and a montmorillonite (M) from Crook County, Wyoming, USA. Both have been supplied by the Source Clay Minerals Repository (University of MO, USA). 2.1 Functionalization of clay minerals Clay minerals were first protonated by suspending 30g of either K or M in 1L of a 2M HCl solution and stirred for 48h. This procedure was repeated 3 times. After proton saturation, clay minerals were first dialyzed (3500Da dialysis tubes) against water until pH 5–6, and then freeze-dried and pulverized. The molecular spacer, 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl-triethoxysilane (Imi-APTS), was synthesized as described elsewhere [20]. Briefly, 260μL (10mmol) of (3-isocyanatopropyl)triethoxysilane and 140μL (11mmol) of N-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole were mixed in 2mL of dioxane, and allowed to react overnight at room temperature under magnetic stirring. 1g of protonated clay mineral was then added to this reaction mixture, and the resulting slurry refluxed at 80°C overnight. The slurry was centrifuged and the residue washed sequentially with dioxane, deionized water and then freeze-dried. The Imi-APTS loading of K and M was determined by elemental analysis (Fisons Elemental Analyzer). 2.2 Immobilization of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl on spacer-functionalized clay minerals Both K and M clay minerals (100mg) functionalized with Imi-APTS were added with 5mL of deionized water containing different amounts of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl (0.30, 0.40, and 10.00mg) and the suspensions stirred overnight at room temperature. The solid residue was separated by centrifugation and exhaustively washed with a 1M NaCl solution and deionized water for removing un-bonded Mn(TDCPPS)Cl. The Mn(TDCPPS)Cl leached from the support was quantified by measuring the amount of catalyst removed in the water washings through UV–vis spectrophotometry (Perkin Elmer Lambda 25) at λ max of 467.4nm. The adducts between Imi-APTS-functionalized clay minerals and Mn-porphyrin were, finally, freeze-dried. A control represented by unfunctionalized K and M clay minerals was similarly prepared by employing 5mL of a aqueous solution containing 0.30mg of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl. 2.3 Cathecol oxidation under heterogeneous catalysis The oxidation reaction of catechol was conducted under stirring at room temperature. The reaction mixture consisted in a final volume of 3mL of 0.25M potassium phosphate buffer at pH=6 that contained 50ppm of catechol, Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on spacer-functionalized solid K or M, and 5mM of H2O2. The following reaction and control mixtures were prepared: (a) 12μmol of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on Imi-APTS-functionalized K; (b) 12μmol of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on Imi-APTS-functionalized M; (c) 240μmol of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on Imi-APTS-functionalized K; (d) 240μmol of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on Imi-APTS-functionalized M; (e) without the immobilized catalyst; (f) without the immobilized catalyst and with 12μmol of free water-soluble Mn(TDCPPS)Cl; (g) without the immobilized catalyst and with 240μmol of free water-soluble Mn(TDCPPS)Cl. The multicyclic potential of immobilized catalysts was verified in sequential reaction cycles: 2 cycles for the 12μmol immobilized catalysts, and 3 cycles for the 240μmol immobilized catalysts. At the end of each cycle, the solid heterogeneous catalyst was separated from the supernatant, washed extensively with deionized water, and freeze-dried before being used in the subsequent reaction cycle. During each reaction cycle, the progress of the oxidative coupling of catechol was followed by a HPLC system consisting of a Perkin-Elmer LC 200 pump, equipped with a 10μL sample loop on a 7125 Rheodyne Rotary Injector, a reverse-phase Sphereclone 5 ODS column (250mm×4.6mm, 5μm, Phenomenex), and two detectors in series (a Perkin-Elmer LS-3B fluorescence spectrometer and a Gilson 118 UV/vis detector). The UV detector was set at 280nm, whereas the excitation/emission wavelengths in the fluorescence detector were set at 278/360nm. The eluent solution was a binary phase of methanol (A) and 0.75% trifluoroacetic acid solution in MilliQ grade water (Millipore) (v/v) (B), that was pumped at 1.2mLmin−1 with the following gradient sequence: eluent A was held for 1min at 2%, increased to 100% in 10min, decreased to 2% in 3min, and finally held at 2% for 3min. A Perkin-Elmer TotalChrom 6.2.0 software was employed to acquire and elaborate chromatograms. Quantitative analysis was based on a calibration curve built with known concentrations of catechol in the 10–50ppm interval. 2.4 NMR spectra Liquid-state 13C NMR spectrum of Imi-APTS spacer was obtained on a 400MHz Bruker Avance spectrometer, equipped with a 5mm Bruker BBI probe, working at a 13C frequency of 100.6MHz at 298±1K, and acquired with 10s thermal equilibrium delay, 12.64μs of 90° pulse length, and a 80ms long proton decoupling Waltz16 sequence, with around 15.6dB power level. The spectrum was acquired with 400 transients and 32k time domain. For a 13C NMR spectral width of 200ppm (20124.6Hz), the spectra free induction decay (FID) was multiplied by 1.5Hz exponential factor without zero filling, baseline corrected and processed by Bruker Topspin Software (v.1.3). The Imi-APTS spacer (0.70mL) was dissolved in 5mm NMR quartz tube using 0.30mL of deuterated chloroform (CDCl3). Carbon-13 cross-polarization magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (13C-CPMAS-NMR) spectra were obtained with a 300MHz Bruker Avance spectrometer equipped with a 4mm wide-bore MAS probe, operating at 75.47MHz on the carbon and with a rotor spin rate of 13,000±1Hz. A recycle time of 1s and an acquisition time of 33ms were used. The 29Si-CPMAS-NMR spectra were obtained similarly to those of carbon but operating at 59.63MHz on the silicon with a rotor spin rate of 5000±1Hz, and a recycle time of 5s. 2.5 X-ray diffractograms The X-ray diffractograms were obtained on oriented clay samples using a Rigaku diffractometer (Rigaku Co, Tokyo) equipped with Cu Kα radiation generated at 35kV and 30mA and a scan speed of 1° 2θ min−1. 2.6 Infrared spectra Diffuse reflectance infrared (DRIFT) spectra were measured on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum-One FT-IR spectrometer in the 4000–600cm−1 range. Spectra were acquired with 8 scans, automatic subtraction of water, smoothing, and baseline correction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Heterogeneous biomimetic catalysts The X-ray diffraction patterns of K and M clay minerals are shown in Fig. 1 , where they are compared with those of K and M functionalized with Imi-APTS spacer. They showed that the functionalization with Imi-APTS did not alter the basal spacing of the K (7.1Å) whereas lowered slightly that of M (from 14.6 to 13.6Å), indicating, in both cases, no intercalation of the spacer between the clay layers. Moreover, in the case of M, the functionalization reaction led to the amorphization of the mineral clay, as evidenced by the disappearance of the small broad peaks and the lowering in intensity of the first X-ray diffraction peak and of the other small sharp peaks. This modify in the clay structure could facilitate the access of the molecular spacer to the clay surface [21] and, thus, explain the higher functionalization degree of M (0.6mmol spacer/g) than K (0.3mmol spacer/g). A structural representation of the adduct between the clay mineral surface and Mn(TDCPPS)Cl via the Imi-APTS is shown in Fig. 2 . The evidence that K and M was actually functionalized with the Imi-APTS spacer was reached by DRIFT-IR and 13C- and 29Si-CPMAS-NMR spectroscopies. The infrared spectrum of the spacer alone (Fig. 3B) shows the characteristic absorptions of the spacer molecule [33]: the stretching (3500–3000cm−1) and bending (1562cm−1) vibrations of the NH amide groups, the weak CH stretching band at 3112cm−1 due to the aromatic imidazole ring, the stretchings of CH3 (2971cm−1) and CH2 (2925cm−1) groups in the spacer chain with the corresponding skeletal bendings at around 1450cm−1, the streching band at 1642cm−1 of CO amide group, and, finally, the 1391cm−1 absorption for the symmetric deformation of CH3 groups. Moreover, the stretching vibrations for the SiOC bonds are visible in the 1100–1000cm−1 range. When the spacer was covalently linked to a clay mineral surface (only the K DRIFT-IR spectrum is shown in Fig. 3A), the corresponding infrared spectrum (Fig. 3C) became deprived of the 2971 and 1391cm−1 bands, thereby proving that the ethoxyl groups in the spacer had reacted with the surface silanols and aluminols of clay minerals. The liquid-state 13C NMR spectrum of the spacer alone and the 13C-CPMAS-NMR spectra of the montmorillonite functionalized with Imi-APTS, are shown in Fig. 4 A and B, respectively. Upon clay mineral functionalization, the 13C-CPMAS-NMR spectrum of M (Fig. 4B) does not show the signals at 17.9 and 57.97ppm for the CH3 and CH2 nuclei, respectively, which pertain to the spacer ethoxyl groups (Fig. 4A). The disappearance of these signals indicates that the reaction between the triethoxysilane group in Imi-APTS and the hydroxyl groups on the clay mineral surface had occurred. The 29Si-CPMAS-NMR spectra of M and K minerals before and after their functionalization with the spacer are reported in Fig. 5 . The spectra of unfunctionalized clay minerals show Si signals for the minerals crystalline structure, which are positioned at −90.99, −99.20, −107.50ppm for montmorillonite (Fig. 5A) and at −91.09ppm for kaolinite (Fig. 5C). After the reaction of minerals with Imi-APTS, the 29Si-CPMAS-NMR spectra of both functionalized M (Fig. 5B) and K (Fig. 5D) reveal three additional signals due to the progressive formation of surface SiOSi siloxane bonds with the three ethoxyl groups of the spacer [34,35]. In particular, the formation of single T1 [RSi(OSi)(OCH2CH3)2], double T2 [RSi(OSi)2(OCH2CH3)], and triple T3 [RSi(OSi)3] siloxane bonds produced signals at around −50, −59, −67ppm, respectively. These Si resonances confirm the occurred covalent linkages between the surface mineral silanols/aluminols and the spacer ethoxyls, thereby proving the mineral functionalization. The percent of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl catalyst immobilized on K and M clay minerals, before and after their functionalization with the imidazole-containing spacer, and as a function of the amount of added catalyst, is reported in Table 1 . The manganese–porphyrin retained on the functionalized minerals, due to an axial coordination between the spacer imidazole nitrogen and the Mn(III) within the porphyrin ring, was nearly quantitative at low amounts (0.30–0.40mg) of catalyst in solution. This is because the occurred specific coordination between Mn(TDCPPS)Cl and the functionalized clay minerals was strong enough to prevent the bound catalyst to be removed by simple washings. The role of the imidazole-containing spacer in strongly retaining the catalyst, appeared evident when the same low amount of dissolved Mn(TDCPPS)Cl was put in contact with the unfunctionalized clay minerals (Table 1). In that case, the catalyst, being only physically and unspecifically adsorbed on mineral surfaces, was washed away completely from M and, substantially, from K, by the water washings following the adsorption reaction. The Mn(TDCPPS)Cl catalyst immobilized on M and K via spacer was, then, characterized by IR spectroscopy (Fig. 6A and C). The bands in the range 4000–1400cm−1 were the same reported in the spectra of M and K functionalized with Imi-APTS, but the aromatic CH stretching band at around 3100cm−1 and the ring breathing band near 1500cm−1 corresponded to, besides the imidazole of spacer, the pyrrole and aromatic rings of manganese–porphyrin supported. 3.2 Catalyzed oxidative coupling of catechol Metal–porphyrins, such as manganese–porphyrins, were shown to couple phenolic compounds through of a radical mechanism. These catalysts are thought to undergo oxidation by producing high-valent metal-oxo species, which can catalyze the oxidation of phenols and produce free radicals [23,36]. The generated radicals may then be quenched by spontaneous and multiple mutual couplings [37], thus resulting into oligo- or poly-mers with enhanced molecular weights, lower solubility, and larger stability against further biological degradation. The catalytic activity of two heterogeneous catalysts, synthesized here as Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on spacer-functionalized K and M, was verified by following the coupling of catechol under H2O2 oxidation, through its disappearance from solution. No substrate oxidation was observed in absence of catalysts, while simple catechol absorption by clay minerals alone was negligible (not shown). Moreover, in order to exclude any imidazolyl co-catalytic contribution by the spacer linked to K and M, but uncapped with Mn(TDCPPS)Cl, additional experiments were run for catechol oxidation in the presence of only the Imi-APTS-functionalized K and M. Also in this case the catechol transformation was nil (not shown), thereby proving that the reaction catalysis was provided only by the immobilized Mn(TDCPPS)Cl and not by any uncapped imidazolyl terminal of the spacer. The UV-detected chromatograms of catechol subjected to the oxidation reaction catalyzed by the two heterogeneous catalysts, revealed a significant decrease of the original substrate in a time-course of about 5h (not shown). The concomitant fluorescence-detected chromatograms showed peaks of reaction products, which eluted at larger elution volumes than catechol, thereby implying less polar structures than the original substrate (not shown). These peaks detected by fluorescence may well be catechol oligomers formed during the oxidative coupling catalyzed by the heterogeneous catalysts. This agrees with previous findings indicating that phenolic monomers are coupled into oligomers under oxidative catalysis [26,27]. Moreover, some of these fluorescent peaks observed here, first increased and then declined during the time course of the catalyzed catechol oxidation, thus suggesting that they represent intermediate and unstable reaction products, which become susceptible of further oxidation, as previously observed [26]. The values for the first-order rate constants calculated for the catechol oxidation catalyzed by either 12 or 240μmol of both the unbound Mn(TDCPPS)Cl catalyst and that immobilized on the spacer-functionalized K and M clay minerals, are reported in Table 2 . The 5h reaction time was selected to limit interferences which may decrease reaction rates, such as oxidant decomposition or catalyst inactivation. The initial reaction period was fitted according to the first-order rate equation, lnc t /c 0 =− kt, where c 0 and c t (moldm−3) represent the substrate concentration in solution at the reaction time of 0 and t (s), respectively, and k (s−1) represents the first-order rate constant. First-order rate reactions were implied by the straight lines (R 2 ≥0.9) obtained by plotting ln (c t ) as a function of reaction time. The catalyst immobilized on both K and M accelerated the rate of catechol oxidation about four times in respect to the rate found for the free catalyst. Moreover, the oxidative coupling reaction was affected by the amount of metal–porphyrin immobilized on the clay minerals. In fact, the rate of catechol oxidation catalyzed by 240μmol of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on spacer-functionalized K and M (Table 2) was about six times larger than for the reaction catalyzed by 12μmol of immobilized catalysts. This indicates that the more concentrated the catalyst, the larger was the number of active sites participating to the reaction and the amount of substrate that underwent oxidative couplings [26]. Moreover, the clay minerals containing the immobilized catalyst were used sequentially in a second and third oxidation reaction. The first-order rate constants measured for such progressive reaction cycles (Table 2) showed that 12μmol of catalyst immobilized on either K or M were still active in the second cycle, though the activity was reduced to that of the free catalyst. Similarly, 240μmol of catalyst immobilized on K provided the same rate constant as for the free catalyst in the second cycle, but the rate substantially decreased in the third cycle. Conversely, 240μmol of Mn(TDCPPS)Cl immobilized on M catalyzed the catechol oxidation reaction in the second cycle to a rate that was still twice as fast as the free catalyst, losing much of its activity only in the third cycle. The decrease in the catalytic activity of reused heterogeneous catalysts could be attributed to the oxidative destruction of manganese–porphyrin, as suggested by the disappearance or weakening of the CH stretching (3100–3000cm−1) and the ring breathing (near 1500cm−1) bands of the aromatic groups inside manganese–porphyrin in the IR spectra of the Mn(TDCPPS)Cl catalyst immobilized on M and K after the third reaction cycle (Fig. 6 B and D). These results thus indicate that heterogeneous adducts formed between Imi-APTS-functionalized K and M clay minerals and Mn(TDCPPS)Cl were more efficient catalysts than the homogeneous Mn(TDCPPS)Cl catalyst. The catalytic activity of heterogeneous biomimetic catalysts significantly increased by 4–5 times in comparison to the free homogeneous catalyst and remained effective for at least two sequential reaction cycles, though with a decrease in reaction rate. 4 Conclusions This work showed that an active biomimetic catalyst such as manganese–porphyrin can be immobilized on largely available clay minerals such as kaolinite and montmorillonite. The activity of the immobilized catalysts was several times larger than that observed by the free catalyst in solution toward the oxidative coupling reaction of a phenolic monomer, that is commonly found in the humified natural organic matter ubiquitous in the environment. Such increased catalytic activity must be attributed to the method of catalyst immobilization on the clay minerals, which was through a spacer linked to the mineral surface by covalent bonds. The flexible spacer chain is capable to coordinate the manganese in the catalyst porphyrin ring through the imidazole nitrogen atom placed at the spacer end. Our results suggest that heterogeneous catalysts, synthesized by immobilizing metal–porphyrins on the surface of spacer-functionalized clay minerals, may be more efficient than the corresponding water-soluble catalysts in leading to stabilization processes of soil humus and in reducing the toxicity of environmentally polluting phenols. coredata.dc:description: Two novel heterogeneous biomimetic catalysts were synthesized by immobilizing a meso-tetra(2,6-dichloro-3-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrinate of manganese (III) chloride on both kaolinite and montmorillonite clay minerals, previously functionalized with a molecular spacer whose terminal nitrogen atom coordinates the metal in the porphyrin ring. The clay functionalization by a 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl-triethoxysilane spacer was proved by X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, DRIFT-IR, 13C- and 29Si-CPMAS-NMR spectroscopies, and the percent of manganese–porphyrin immobilized by the spacer coordination calculated by spectrophotometry. The activity of the novel catalysts was evaluated in the oxidative coupling reaction of catechol, a humic phenol, using H2O2 as oxygen donor. The rate of catechol oxidation catalyzed by both heterogeneous catalysts was about four times as fast as that catalyzed by the free manganese–porphyrin, and depended on the amount of catalyst immobilized on clay minerals. Moreover, the activity of the heterogeneous catalysts remained effective for at least two sequential reaction cycles, although at a decreasing rate. We showed that the immobilization of a biomimetic catalyst on clay minerals increased the catalytic efficiency and allowed the catalyst recycling and reuse for additional reactions. Metal–porphyrins immobilized on clay minerals through a flexible spacer may act as environment-friendly heterogeneous catalysts to control phenolic molecules in environmental humus.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catechol oxidation by heterogeneous biomimetic catalysts immobilized on clay minerals
